title: We humans have miniaturized dog breeds through selective breeding, but have we tried this with plants? - Quora

response.answer_text: In some cases, yes, but most often, with plants, we either: Want them bigger to produce more for us instead of lessGiant pumpkin contests are more of our natural impulse that tiny pumpkin contests.  Can keep them smaller via pruning or other methods rather than requiring selective breedingBonsai trees are genetically identical to big ones, but pruning and potting techniques can keep them tiny for literally a hundred years.  That said, there are cases where we do want naturally smaller plants either to fit into smaller spaces (dwarf fruit trees, dwarf roses), or to reduce the non-product parts of the plant (dwarf wheat). These varieties have been achieved by basically all of the methods we know how to use with plants - grafting, cross-breeding/cross-pollinating, gene editing, and even blasting with radiation to produce novel mutations we can select between. Dwarf fruit tree ideal for tiny spaces  Dwarf wheat spends less energy getting tall so it makes more grains faster and is more wind-resistant.

Oh, why not! Dwarfism is one of the important features to have in cultivated plants. The ‘green-revolution’ which paved way for self-sufficiency in wheat and rice production throughout the world were due to the breeding of semi-dwarf cultivated varieties of these two crops.
